SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A work of exhaustion to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer List: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

A good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With a family returning to Canada.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train + boat

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way! Meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

The calculation on CPR was made by handboard from that point we traveled by handboard and train. 60 mile to Qu'Appelle Creek, south side of Cypress Hill. A broken single tree necessitated my returning alone via a narrow beam all night while my friend continued by horseback to nearest rancher for repair. He returned about 6 a.m.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Qu'Appelle Creek, 60 miles from Great No. 1.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Train to Regina Aug. 1902. Prairieway Ranch.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Lethbridge, 1907

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Clerical work in England
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Traveling on CPR was very smooth.

From that point we traveled by train and boat.

60 miles to Buxton, then walked along the side of Cypress Hill. A shorter distance than anticipated due to remaining alone in a snowstorm all night while my friend continued by horseback 15 minutes toward for supplies. We arrived about 6 a.m.
